container-title: The philosophical aspects are thoroughly gone into in Peter Caws: Structuralism: The Art of the Intelligible
title: The most comprehensive and rigorous of the general books remains that by the eminent Swiss psychologist, Jean Piaget: Structuralism
is angled towards mathematics and the sciences, and is not always easy reading

container-title: contains the proceedings of a conference held in 1966, with contributions both for and against Structuralism by, among others
note: consists of five explanatory essays by specialists on the thought of Ltvi-Strauss, Barthes, Foucault, Lacan and Derrida. Finally, for a shrewdly sceptical account of Structuralism as a movement, see Thomas Pavel, The Feud of Language: A History of Structuralist Thought
Further Reading
title: Two other valuable studies written from a philosophical point of view are: Philip Pettit, The Concept of Structuralism: A Critical Analysis (University of California Press, 1977);and Howard Gardner, The Quest for Mind: Piaget, Le'vi-Strauss and the Structuralist Movement
More concerned with Structuralism's linguistic and literary dimensions is Terence Hawkes's elegantly written Structuralism and Semiotics
commendably straightforward general account is Roland A. Champagne: French Structuralism
contains seven magisterial lectures given in Oxford by prominent specialists. The Languages of Criticism and the Sciences of Man

container-title: An excellent short study of Saussure's ideas is Jonathan Culler's Modern Master volume
title: The absolutely key text is Ferdinand de Saussure's Course in General Linguistics
This translation is preferable to the earlier one made by Wade Baskin
More advanced but highly instructive is Roy Harris's Reading Saussure
valuable as a close analytical reading of Saussure's principal linguistic ideas is David Holdcroft's Saussure: Signs, System, and Arbitrariness
The spread of Saussurian ways of thinking is covered in Francoise Gadet: Saussure and Contemporary Culture
The North American tradition of linguistic Structuralism is well exemplified in two general books: Edward Sapir's compact and comprehensive Language: An Introduction to the Science of Speech

note: For a clear, authoritative and up-to-date survey of Chomsky's ideas there is John Lyons's Modern Master volume,
title: Bloomfield's Language
includes Bloomfield's interesting 1923 review of Saussure's Cours. Of a more technical kind and not for beginners is Zellig S. Harris: Structural Linguistics
The best introduction to the ideas of Noam Chomsky is probably to be had from the annotated reader, Chomsky: Selected Readings
of Chomsky's own books which are aimed at non-specialist readers are Language and Mind

container-title: as can the French linguist Emile Benveniste's Problems in General Linguistics
title: Of theorists working in the Structuralist tradition of Saussure, two stand out. The Dane Louis Hjelmslev's Prolegomena to a Theory of Language can be read in an English
A very clear and helpful general textbook founded on Structuralist principles is Andrt Martinet's Elements of General Linguistics

note: More technical is the principal work of Jakobson's foremost Russian collaborator, N. S Troubetskoy, Principles of Phonology
title: The influence of phonology on Structuralism can be well traced in Roman Jakobson's Six Lessons on Sound and Meaning
This has an introduction by Ltvi-Strauss, which provides interesting evidence of the direct influence of Jakobson's method of phonological analysis on his own method in social anthropology

Much recent work published by philosophers of language in Britain and the United States bears closely on the subject-matter of the present book. The first three chapters Further Reading of John Passmore's Recent Philosophers
link Structuralism very lucidly to contemporary Anglo-American philosophy. A valuable reader, containing major essays by both theoretical linguists and philosophers is The Philosophy of Linguistics

container-title: in which he analyses a large number of North American Indian myths
note: have all been translated into English. They are specialized and repetitive, but the introduction to the first volume, The Raw and the Cooked (1970), and the postscript to the last, The Naked Man
title: Structuralist anthropology has been dominated by the work of Claude Lkvi-Strauss. His ideas are to be found most clearly expressed in the two volumes of Structural Anthropology
Grundfest Schoepf
well worth reading are his autobiographical volume Tristes tropiques
The four volumes of his Mythologiques
very illuminating as a summary of Lt-vi-Strauss's methods and philosophical views. For a lucid and often critical assessment of his work, see E
The application of Structuralist methods in the study and writing of history is a matter magisterially treated in Fernand Braudel's O n History
Similarly, the essays of another French historian, Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie, are often highly relevant: see in particular The Territory of the Historian

note: the growing number of books written on Foucault in English, the most useful are Hubert L. Dreyfus and Paul Rabinow, Michel Foucault: Beyond Structuralism and Hermeneutics (Chicago University Press, 1982), and Foucault: A Critical Reader (ed.
title: A collective volume by French historians containing much that is useful is Constructing the Past: Essays in Historical Methodology
Peter Burke's History and Social Theory

also contains a discussion of how the notion of 'structure' is not understood by historians. By no means all of Michel Foucault's published writings can be described as Structuralist. Those deserving inclusion here are The Order of Things: An Archaeology of the Human Sciences
The Archaeology of Knowledge

container-title: and James Miller's ambitious and highly enlightening The Passion of Michel Foucault

Two biographies of Foucault have appeared: Didier Eribon's informative but cautious Michel Foucault

His extraordinary autobiography, recounting the very troubled story of his emotional life and the genesis of his philosophical ideas, appeared in English under the title The Future Lasts a Long Time

title: Sigmund Freud may certainly be claimed as a proto-Structuralist in his theories of the human psyche. Good access to his main ideas may be got from his Introductory Lectures on Psychoanalysis

container-title: and The Seminar, Books One and Two
Among the more instructive ones are E. Ragland-Sullivan, Jacques Lacan and the Philosophy of Psychoanalysis
and David Macey, Lacan in Contexts
title: The writings of Freud's celebrated French disciple, Jacques Lacan, are notoriously difficult. A selection of his major essays is contained in Ecrits: A Selection
More accessible are The Four Fundamental Concepts of Psychoanalysis
Books about Lacan in English have proliferated
Soshana Felman: Jacques Lacan and the Adventure of Insight
But far and away the best short exposition of Lacan's thought is in Malcolm Bowie's Modern Master, Lacan

publisher: Charles Hartshorne and Paul Weiss. Harvard University Press

The leading European writer on the subject has been the Italian, Umberto Eco. His A Theory of Semiotics

title: In the United States Post-Structuralism is better known under the name of Deconstruction, a radical school of literary thought that has quickly given rise to a huge academic literature, both for and against. The outstanding US deconstructionist was Paul de Man, whose subtle and sometimes elusive work is contained in Blindness and Insight: Essays in the Rhetoric of Contemporary Criticism

note: Christopher Norris's Deconstruction: Theory and Practice (London: Methuen, 1982); and Vincent B. Leitch's Deconstructive Criticism: An Advanced Introduction (London: Hutchinson, 1983).
title: Another major American critic influenced by Deconstruction is Geoffrey Hartman: see especially his Criticism in the Wilderness; The Study of Literature Today
Lucid general accounts of Deconstruction are: Jonathan Culler's O n Deconstruction: Theory and Criticism after Structuralism
For a negative response: John M. Ellis: Against Deconstruction
